book-title-group.subtitle: Luther, Kierkegaard, and the Binding of Isaac

abstract.p: The story of the binding of Isaac both challenges and inspires people who seek to live faithfully in relationship with a God who surpasses our understanding. Combinding the history of exegesis with a theological exploration of the meaning of faith in the face of suffering, this book examines Luther‘s and Kierkegaard‘s lively--and very different--interpretations of Genesis 22 to demonstrate how the way we read the Bible is crucial to the life of faith.

title-group.title: Pedagogy and Anagogy in Twentieth-Century Readings of Genesis 22

abstract.p: In his renowned literary comparison of Genesis 22 with Homer’s account of Odysseus’s homecoming, Erich Auerbach reminds readers that the most provocative interactions between a reader and a religious text may play out in the silences in the story, the spaces that elude narrative logic and move the reader from certainty toward the frightening aporia that underlies the relationship between humans and their God.

title-group.title: Faith as Movement in Relation to Fear and Trembling

abstract.p: What is Kierkegaard really attempting to do or say with this text? This question must be posed in relation to larger claims about faith in Kierkegaard’s perspective before the effects of the text upon its readers in relation to their own perception of God can be accurately examined. title-group.title: The Value of Anagogical Exegesis for Faith

abstract.p: The performative dimensions of Luther and Kierkegaard’s readings of Genesis 22 have been evaluated in light of each thinker’s concept of faith as perceptual movement in relation to the hiddenness and revelation of God. Such performative movement can be called anagogical when it moves the reader into deeper understanding of God. Both theLectures on GenesisandFear and Tremblingmove their readers in ways that resemble a movement of faith: toward a trustworthy God for the former, and into the abyss of God’s ineffability for the latter.
